de.brands4friends.daleq.core

Interface Row


  • public interface Row
    Used to build a Row in a relational database table.

    Logically, Row represents a row in a table. It has an id and consists of a list of fields. Fields are not modelled explicitly, which means there is no class representing fields, but only through Row's capability to specify the content of a field. A row always belongs to Table.

    A row is always created and associated with an id. This id is used to either define the value of the primary key and to be used as a source for Daleq to deterministically choose the value of an non explicitly specified field. It is Daleq's basic idea to just specify what is subject to a particular test and to leave out what is unimportant. Nonetheless a database table has to be filled with some content. Therefore Daleq decides for each field, which has not been defined explicitly with f(de.brands4friends.daleq.core.FieldTypeReference, java.lang.Object), which value is set to the field. Generally this depends on the field's particular type and sometimes even on the respective database, the table is written to. Daleq takes care, that each value is created in a deterministic fashion, hence each run of a test is faced with exactly the same data.

    Technically, Row is a builder. It will collect the Row's id and all explicitly set fields to build the data holding entity RowData.

    Use Daleq.aRow(long) to create an instance of Row. We encourage to static import this method to benefit from Daleq's embedded DSL.

    See Also:
    Table, Daleq, TypeConverter

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      RowData build(Context context, TableType tableType)
      Constructs the actual data holding entity.
      Row f(FieldTypeReference fieldTypeReference, java.lang.Object value)
      Defines the value of a field.

    • Method Detail

      • f

        Row f(FieldTypeReference fieldTypeReference,
    @Nullable
    java.lang.Object value)
        Defines the value of a field.

        If a field is defined multiple times, the last definition is used.

        Parameters:
        fieldTypeReference - References the field, which should be set. Since the row will finally end up in a Table, the Field has to belong the table's meta model. As matter of fact this is not checked, when field is added with method call, but rather when the table is built.
        value - Sets the fields value. Daleq has a sophisticated strategy to calculate the value which is finally written into the database. If value is a (boxed) primitive type, it is directly written to the DB. If it is a subclass of Object, then Daleq checks if there is a registered TypeConverter for this class and uses it, otherwise the class' toString() method is used. If you want to write null to the database, just set If value to null.
        Returns:
        the instance of row itself
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if fieldTypeReference is null

      • build

        RowData build(Context context,
            TableType tableType)
        Constructs the actual data holding entity.

        Since Row is just a builder, at some point Daleq has to construct the entities, holding the database table content. In general this method is not expected to be called by client code, but only by Daleq's internal code.

        Parameters:
        context - provides contextual information, which are required to build a RowData
        tableType - the type of the meta model, to which the row belongs.
        Returns:
        an entity holding the row's content
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if context is null
        NoSuchDaleqFieldException - if any field in the row contains does not belong to the table's meta model.
